questions.text:
Match the following with their correct terms.


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Exon
			
			
			i
			
			
			Non-coding region
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Intron
			
			
			ii
			
			
			One of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Locus
			
			
			iii
			
			
			Coding region
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Allele
			
			
			iv
			
			
			Location of a gene on the chromosome
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1-iii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-ii

 

Explanation:

 

Exon:

  • An exon is a coding region of a gene that contains the genetic information necessary for producing a functional protein.

 

Intron:

  • An intron is a non-coding region of a gene that intervenes between exons.
  • During gene expression, introns are removed from the pre-mRNA molecule through splicing, which allows exons to be joined together to form the final mRNA transcript before translation into a protein.

 

Locus:

  • A locus refers to the specific location of a gene or DNA sequence on a chromosome.

 

Allele:

  • An allele is one of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome, which can lead to different traits or characteristics.
  • Alleles can be dominant or recessive.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male from a tribal area of Madhya Pradesh presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. On examination, he appears pale, and jaundice is noted. Laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin levels and increased reticulocyte count. The peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle-shaped erythrocytes. What is the most likely molecular mechanism underlying the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Missense mutation


 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a tribal male with the above-mentioned clinical features and sickle-shaped RBCs in the peripheral smear suggests sickle cell disease. A missense mutation (type of point mutation) is the underlying mechanism in the pathogenesis of this disease.

 

Point mutation:

  • A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base.
  • Sickle cell anaemia.
    • This point mutation involves substituting adenine for thymine at the seventh codon of the β-globin gene (GAG to GTG), replacing glutamic acid with valine in the β-globin chain of haemoglobin.
    • This single nucleotide change results in the formation of abnormal haemoglobin molecules (HbS).

questions.text: A couple visits a genetics counselor due to concerns about their baby's blood type. The father has blood type A (genotype IAIA), and the mother has blood type B (genotype IBIB). The counselor explains that blood type is determined by codominant alleles, where both alleles contribute equally to the phenotype in the heterozygous condition. Which of the following best describes codominance?

choices.text: One allele completely masks the expression of the other allele
The phenotype of the heterozygote is intermediate between the phenotypes of the homozygotes
Only one allele is expressed, while the other remains silent
Both alleles contribute to the phenotype equally in the heterozygous condition

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Both alleles contribute to the phenotype equally in the heterozygous condition

 

Explanation:

 

Codominance can be defined as a condition in which both the alleles of a gene pair in a heterozygote are equally expressed.

Examples:

 

ABO blood group system
  • In the ABO blood group system, the IA and IB alleles are codominant in producing the AB blood group phenotype, in which both A and B-type antigens are produced.
  • The genes responsible for the ABO blood group are located in chromosome 9.
  • The presence of both IA and IB causes the expression of both, forming the AB blood group.
  • HLA gene also shows co dominance

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of tall stature, long limbs, and joint hypermobility. Upon further examination, he also exhibits features such as a high-arched palate, arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers), and aortic root dilation. His father has a similar appearance. Which of the following statements is true regarding the inheritance pattern seen in this condition?

choices.text: Males are more commonly affected than females.
Most mutations lead to reduced production of a gene product or give rise to a dysfunctional or inactive protein.
The least common mode of inheritance

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Most mutations lead to reduced production of a gene product or give rise to a dysfunctional or inactive protein.

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of a male with tall stature, long limbs, joint hypermobility, arachnodactyly, aortic root dilatation, and similar features in his father suggests Marfan’s syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition and gene FBN1 (fibrillin-1) on chromosome 15.

The true statement regarding autosomal dominant inheritance is that most proteins lead to reduced production of a gene product or give rise to a dysfunctional or inactive protein.

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance:

  • Autosomal dominant disorders are manifested in the heterozygous state, so at least one parent of an index case is usually affected.
  • It is the most common mode of inheritance. (Option D)
  • Both males and females are affected, and both can transmit the condition. (Option A)
  • They are characterized by:
    • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some proportion of patients do not have affected parents.
    • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity:
      • Some individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal. This is referred to as incomplete penetrance. (Option C)
      • If a trait is seen in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals, the phenomenon is called variable expressivity.
  • In many conditions the age at onset is delayed; symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents to the pediatric clinic with failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and hepatosplenomegaly. Upon further examination, the infant also displays signs of skeletal abnormalities including bowed legs and frontal bossing. Lab investigations reveal pancytopenia with markedly decreased platelet count. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Gaucher disease. What is the pattern of inheritance and underlying genetic defect leading to this disorder?

choices.text: Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the CFTR Gene
X-linked Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene
Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the HEXA Gene
Autosomal Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Autosomal Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene

Explanation:

Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase - GBA1 gene.

 

  • All lysosomal storage diseases are autosomal recessive

  • Exceptions (X-linked recessive): Fabry disease & Hunter syndrome

 

Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the CFTR Gene (Option A): Cystic fibrosis (CF) is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. (chromosome 7)

 

X-linked Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene (Option B): Gaucher disease is not associated with X-linked inheritance; instead, it follows autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the HEXA Gene (Option C): Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HEXA gene, resulting in deficient activity of the enzyme β-hexosaminidase A.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly, failure to thrive, and hypotonia. The infant has a cherry-red spot on the macula and exhibits poor startle reflexes on physical examination. Further evaluation reveals foam cells in the bone marrow. What is the diagnosis and associated enzyme deficiency?

choices.text: Diagnosis: Niemann-Pick disease type A, Enzyme Deficiency: Acid sphingomyelinase
Diagnosis: Tay-Sachs disease, Enzyme Deficiency: Hexosaminidase A
Diagnosis: Gaucher disease, Enzyme Deficiency: Glucocerebrosidase
Diagnosis: Metachromatic leukodystrophy, Enzyme Deficiency: Arylsulfatase A

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Diagnosis: Niemann-Pick disease type A, Enzyme Deficiency: Acid sphingomyelinase

Explanation:

  • Cause – Niemann–Pick disease is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency, leading to sphingomyelin accumulation.
  • Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin, progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life.
  • In contrast, patients with type B disease have organomegaly but generally no central nervous system involvement. Patients usually survive into adulthood.
  • Affected cells become enlarged, due to the distention of lysosomes with sphingomyelin and cholesterol, imparting foaminess to the cytoplasm.

Image: Niemann-Pick disease in the liver. The hepatocytes and Kupffer cells have a foamy, vacuolated appearance due to the deposition of lipids.

Electron microscopy confirms that the vacuoles are engorged secondary lysosomes called zebra bodies.

Image: Zebra bodies

questions.text: Sarah is a 3-year-old girl who is brought to her pediatrician by her parents due to concerns about her development. Her parents report that Sarah has been experiencing a loss of previously acquired skills, such as hand skills and language, stereotypic hand movements and seizure episodes . What is the mode of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) X-linked dominant

 

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations in the patients point to Rett Syndrome. It has X-linked dominant inheritance. X-linked dominant disorders affect both males and females.

  • All fathers that are affected by an X-linked dominant disorder will have affected daughters but not affected sons.
  • However, if the mother is also affected then sons will have a chance of being affected, depending on whether a dominant or recessive X chromosome is passed on. When the son is affected, the mother will always be affected.

Examples of X-linked dominant disorders (Mnemonic: RAVI-C):

  1. Rett Syndrome
  2. Alport Syndrome (X-linked)
  3. Vitamin D-dependent rickets
  4. Incontinentia Pigmenti
  5. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with severe hypotonia at birth, joint hypermobility, scoliosis, fragile skin, and ocular fragility. Genetic testing reveals mutations in the gene encoding Lysyl Hydroxylase. Which subtype of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is most likely present in this patient and its mode of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kyphoscoliotic EDS - Autosomal Recessive

Explanation:

A young male with severe hypotonia at birth, joint hypermobility, scoliosis, fragile skin, ocular fragility and mutations in the gene encoding Lysyl Hydroxylase points towards Kyphoscoliotic EDS (Type VI), which is Autosomal Recessive.

questions.text: What type of inheritance pattern is associated with hypertrichosis pinnae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Holandric

Explanation:

Hypertrichosis, characterized by excessive hair growth on ears, is a rare genetic condition that can be associated with genes located on the Y chromosome. Since the Y chromosome is only present in males and is passed from fathers to sons, holandric traits are exclusively observed in males and are inherited from fathers.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to excessive bleeding after a minor injury. His mother reports that his grandfather also had similar bleeding episodes. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in factor IX. What is the mode of inheritance for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) X-linked recessive

 

Explanation:

Factor IX deficiency, associated with Hemophilia B, is an X-linked recessive disorder that predominantly affects males, as evidenced by the family history.

 

X-Linked Recessive:

  • The gene for Hemophilia B is located on the X chromosome.
  • Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation.
  • Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X.
  • Affected males cannot pass the disorder to sons but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers.
  • Hemophilia A and B is X linked recessive
  • Hemophilia C is autosomal recessive 

 



 

X-linked Recessive

(WISE ABCDEFGH)
  • Wise-Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  • AB- Hemophilia A, B
  • B- Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia.
  • C- Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red Green Color Blindness
  • D- DMD, BMD
  • E- Lesch Nyhan Syndrome
  • F- Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome
  • G- G6PD Deficiency
  • H- Hunter Disease

questions.text: If the mother and father have the β-thalassemia trait, what percentage of their children are expected to have β-thalassemia major?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 25%

 

Explanation:

There is a 25% chance that their child will inherit the genotype β⁰/β⁰, corresponding to β-thalassemia major.

 

Mother's Genotype: β/β⁰ (carrier for β-thalassemia)

Father's Genotype: β/β⁰ (carrier for β-thalassemia)

 

Punnett Square Analysis:

Possible Outcomes:

  1. β/β (Normal): 25%
  2. β/β⁰ (Carrier): 50%
  3. β⁰/β⁰ (β-thalassemia major): 25%

questions.text: If a mother has sickle cell trait and the father has sickle cell disease , what percentage of their children are expected to have sickle cell disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 50%

 

 

Explanation:

There is a 50% chance that their child will inherit the genotype SS, which corresponds to sickle cell disease.

 

Mother's Genotype: AS (carrier)

Father's Genotype: SS (sickle cell disease)
